qas.question: What is the last origination of the word asphalt?
From what language does asphalt initially come?
What are the meanings of the Greek word for asphalt?
What is the French term for natural asphalt?
To construct what feature was asphalt brought to Babylon?
From where is the word limestone derived?
In Greek, what is the term asphalte used for?
According to who was bitumen brought to Greece to build a giant wall?
In what language is asphalte used for synthetically occurring bitumen soaked limestones?

context: The word asphalt is derived from the <a0_0><b5_0>late Middle English<b5_0/><a0_0/>, in turn from French asphalte, based on Late Latin asphalton, asphaltum, which is the latinisation of the <a1_0>Greek<a1_0/> ἄσφαλτος (ásphaltos, ásphalton), a word meaning "<a2_0>asphalt/bitumen/pitch<a2_0/>", which perhaps derives from ἀ-, "without" and σφάλλω (sfallō), "make fall". Note that in <b8_0>French<b8_0/>, the term <a3_0>asphalte<a3_0/> is used for <b6_0>naturally occurring bitumen-soaked limestone deposits<b6_0/>, and for specialised manufactured products with fewer voids or greater bitumen content than the "asphaltic concrete" used to pave roads. It is a significant fact that the first use of asphalt by the ancients was in the nature of a cement for securing or joining together various objects, and it thus seems likely that the name itself was expressive of this application. Specifically <b7_0>Herodotus<b7_0/> mentioned that bitumen was brought to Babylon to build its gigantic fortification <a4_0>wall<a4_0/>. From the Greek, the word passed into late Latin, and thence into French (asphalte) and English ("asphaltum" and "asphalt").
